clk(clock signal) - This <br />
d - input(Data input) <br />
reset - resets the the D Flip Flop back to an original state <br />

What is Edge Triggering? <br />
Edge triggering is a type of triggering that allows a circuit to become active at the positive edge or the negative edge of the clock signal. <br /> <br />

**D FLIP FLOP** <br /> <br />
![alt text](data:image/png;base64,) <br /> <br />

![alt text](https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-6vOQ3m8hgYA/VztXGO-ecWI/AAAAAAAAA3Y/V4o3mwm3PVsMlk7tM8ZEHv2fyc7UickogCK4B/s1600/Edge%2BTriggiring.jpg) <br />


**CIRCUIT DIAGRAM** <br /> <br />
![alt text](https://static.javatpoint.com/tutorial/digital-electronics/images/d-flip-flop2.png) <br /> <br />

**TRUTH TABLE** <br /> <br />
![alt text](https://static.javatpoint.com/tutorial/digital-electronics/images/d-flip-flop3.png) <br /> <br />

+ The D in D Flip-Flop stands for Data i.e. this Flip-Flop stores the value on the data line. 
+ When the data input is set to 1, the flip flop would be set, and when it is set to 0, the flip flop would change and become reset. 
+ However, the ouptut of the flip flop would change on every pulse applied to this input. 
+ Hence, we use a clock. <br /> 
+ When the clock input is set to true, the D input condition is only copied to the output Q. <br />
    When the clock input is set to 1, the "set" and "reset" inputs of the flip-flop are both set to 1. So it will not change the state and store the data present on its output before the clock transition occurred.

+ So, in conclusion, we can say that the D Flip flop will only change its stored value during an edge trigger i.e., when the input changes from 1 to 0 (or) 0 to 1.
